doc.field: Hostage taking in Luebeck prison resolved without bloodshed

A hostage-taking attempt in a Luebeck prison has been ended by police without bloodshed. A murder convict had threatened the institution's psychologist and the wife of the executive prosecutor with a knife for five hours. The hostage-taker left the building with the wife of Luebeck prosecutor Heinrich Wilde. He forced his hostage to get into the driver's seat of the car that he had demanded for his flight. The man took the seat behind his hostage. Shortly after the car had started moving a flash grenade exploded next to the hostage-taker. While he was still blinded and stunned, police opened the doors, rescued the hostage, and overpowered the criminal.
Talks between Kohl and Stoiber about introduction of Euro

Chancellor Helmut Kohl considers the continuing discussion about the introduction of a common European currency hardly meaningful. Outside Germany the debate was not being understood anyway, Kohl said at the Bavarian Employers Congress. The Chancellor asserted that Germany will meet the Maastricht deficit criteria to the point. Bavaria's State Premier Edmund Stoiber was satisfied with Kohl's statement to meet the deficit criterion of 3.0 percent. After their addresses both met for short four-eye talks. No information was available on the subject. Stoiber had caused tensions between Bonn and Munich by repeatedly demanding to delay the introduction of the common currency Euro if there was an emergency situation.
Numerous law changes become effective today

Millions of citizens are affected by law changes that take effect today, July 1. The third stage of the health reform requires that patients belonging to public health insurers now pay a higher portion of medicaments and 15% for other health services such as massages. Exceptions have been provided for people in need. There were also changes in the vehicle tax. Cars whose exhausts are below the Euronorm 2 threshold will be taxed less, others will be taxed higher. In the public service the automatic promotion of civil servants has been ended. In addition, executive positions will only be awarded after a one-year trial period. Finally, premiums and benefits have been introduced to increase performance.
German government continues support of Eurofighter jet
The German government will continue the support of the disputed Eurofighter jet. Defence Minister Volker Ruehe had a statement released that the new fighter jet is included in next year's budget.
Poisonous substances released in chemical accident in Dormagen

During an accident in the chemical plant of Bayer AG in Dormagen, North-Rhine Westphalia, several tons of a poisonous substance have been released. According to a company spokesperson nobody was injured and there was no danger for the environment. Last night, a pipe had burst on the factory compound. The cause remains still unknown. The released chemical is used in the production of foamed plastics and is considered to cause cancer.
Trial against alleged extortionist of German Railways has begun

Today marks the beginning of the trial against the alleged extortionist of German Railways. The 36-year-old allegedly tried to extort several million DM by sabotaging rail tracks. He is said to have German Railways for the first time in December 1994 announcing an attack on an ICE high-speed train. He demanded up to DM2 million in ransom on behalf of the alias "The Mummies". Amongst others, he allegedly has turned lose rail bolts on a line Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania causing a local train to derail. A bomb attack on the Berlin-Potsdam line had no severe consequences. The accused has not yet addressed the accusations but stated that he has been an active environmentalist.
Teachers of Hesse rally against savings
There was no school today in parts of Hesse because several thousand teachers demonstrated in Frankfurt against cuts in the education sector.
Electronic tapping of cars legal
The Federal High Court has found that police may open cars and install tapping devices when the car user is suspected of a serious crime.
Three killed in airplane crash
Three people, two adults and one child died when a private plane crashed shortly after take-off. The cause of the accident is still unknown.
Tennis: Stich, Becker, and Kiefer in Wimbledon quarter finals

Michael Stich has reached the quarter finals of the Wimbledon tournament. He won over Australian Mark Woodforde in 4 sets. Boris Becker got into the quarter finals by beating Mercelo Rios in 3 sets. Kiefer eliminated the #3 seated Yevgeny Kafelnikov.
